title: 103_hr2632
content: The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for the Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal year 1994. This amount will be derived from deposits in the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. Additionally, fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946 will also be made available to the office for fiscal year 1994. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. Trademark filing fee set at $245, with adjustments not effective before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code is amended to allow for interim patent extensions if the regulatory review period extends beyond the patent term. The owner or agent can apply for an extension 6 months before the term expires. The owner or agent can apply for an interim extension of a patent 6 months before it expires. The application must include details about the product under review, the patent being extended, and the applicant's activities during the regulatory review period. The Commissioner may grant an interim extension of a patent if it would be eligible for extension under this section. The owner of the patent can apply for this extension, which lasts for up to 1 year. The application must include details of the product under review, the patent, and the applicant's activities during the regulatory review period. The Commissioner may grant an interim extension of a patent for up to 1 year. The owner of record can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions, with exceptions for certain patents. Each extension must be applied for within a specific timeframe before the expiration of the previous extension. The certificate of interim extension is considered part of the original patent and is recorded in the official file. Any interim extension granted terminates 60 days after the date of issuance. Any interim extension granted under this paragraph shall terminate at the end of the 60-day period beginning on the date on which the product involved receives permission for commercial marketing or use. If the applicant notifies the Commissioner of such permission within that 60-day period and submits additional information, the patent may be further extended for up to 5 years from the original patent term expiration date. During an interim extension, a patent's rights are limited to the specific use or method under regulatory review. The extension lasts for up to 5 years from the original patent term expiration date or until the product receives approval for commercial use. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, including changes to subsections (a), (b), and (e). SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. The term of certain design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion is extended for 14 years from the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not infringe on any patent for activities that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
